Bob Nichols | past_members = }} '''Marley's Ghost''' is a band based in [[Washington (state)|Washington]] and [[Northern California]] which has existed since the mid-1980s and has recorded 12 albums. While their music has a strong [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] emphasis, their musical style is diverse. ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' magazine has described them as "a decidedly unusual band, as capable of reanimating [[Appalachian folk music|Appalachian folk songs]] as they are traditional [[Celtic music|Celtic]] fare, [[honky tonk]] and [[reggae]]."{{cite web|url=http://www.cybergrass.com/modules.php?name%3DNews%26file%3Darticle%26sid%3D7059 |title=Cybergrass Bluegrass Music News: Marley's Ghost taps Cowboy Jack Clement for new CD, 'Ghost Town' |access-date=2009-11-30 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104033746/http://cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=7059 |archivedate=2010-01-04 }} ==History== Dan Wheetman, Jon Wilcox, and Mike Phelan met in March 1986 in the [[San Fernando Valley]] during [[Saint Patrick's Day]] shows. That winter, Wheetman went to Littlefield's studio to record a solo album, bringing Wilcox and Phelan. They ended up recording the first three Marley's Ghost albums before completing Wheetman's solo album.{{cite web |url=http://conqueroo.com/marleysghostbio.html|title=Marley's Ghost|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=June 13, 2017|author=Joel Selvin}} In 2006, [[Van Dyke Parks]] produced ''Spooked'', and artist [[Robert Crumb]] illustrated the album cover. (Crumb and Wheetman knew each other from an earlier musical venture, [[R. Crumb & His Cheap Suit Serenaders]], of which Wheetman was a member for a short time in the mid-1970s.)Lynch, Megan. [https://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-cheap-suit-serenaders-mn0001823325/biography "The Cheap Suit Serenaders,"] AllMusic.com. Accessed Nov. 17, 2019. Guests on the recording included [[Bill Frisell]] (guitar), [[Buell Neidlinger]] (bass), and Don Heffington (drums).{{cite web |url=http://www.antimusic.com/news/05/nov/1701.shtml|title=Marley's Ghost Taps Van Dyke Parks|work=antiMUSIC|access-date=June 5, 2017|author= }} Released in 2012, ''Jubilee'' was produced by [[Cowboy Jack Clement]], and includes performances by [[Emmylou Harris]], [[John Prine]], [[Marty Stuart]], and [[Old Crow Medicine Show]].{{cite news|last1=Spoerl|first1=Steven|title=Marley's Ghost: Jubilee|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/160578-marleys-ghost-jubilee/|access-date=June 13, 2017|work=Popmatters|date=12 August 2012}} 2017's ''The Woodstock Sessions'' was recorded at [[Levon Helm]]’s studio in [[Woodstock, New York]]. [[Larry Campbell (musician)|Larry Campbell]] produced this album of mostly traditional music.{{cite news|last1=Rhodes|first1=Mick|title=Marley's Ghost brings eclectic mix to Claremont|url=https://www.claremont-courier.com/mobile/article/t20129-marley|access-date=June 13, 2017|work=[[Claremont Courier]]|date=August 17, 2016}} 2019's ''Travelin' Shoes'' was also produced by Larry Campbell and features a host of gone-world gospel gems. ==Personnel== * Mike Phelan: [[Guitar]]s, [[Dobro]], [[Bass guitar|bass]], [[fiddle]], lead & harmony vocals, writer. * Ed Littlefield Jr.: [[Pedal steel guitar|Pedal steel]], guitars, bass, fiddle, [[Highland bagpipes]] lead & bass vocals * Dan Wheetman: Bass, [[National Steel Guitar|National Steel]], Fiddle, Guitar, lead & harmony vocals, writer. * Jon Wilcox: [[Mandolin]], guitar, [[Irish bouzouki]] lead & harmony vocals, writer * Jerry Fletcher: [[Keyboard instrument|Keyboards]], harmony vocals * Bob Nichols: Drums, percussion ==Discography== * 1987: ''Haunting Melodies'' (Sage Arts) * 1989: ''Let De Groove Rise Up'' (Sage Arts) -
